008 ******************************************************************************/
009package imagingbook.common.filter.generic;
010
011import imagingbook.common.image.PixelPack;
012import imagingbook.common.image.PixelPack.PixelSlice;
013
014/**
015 * This (abstract) class represents a generic scalar filter whose pixel-operation is x/y-separable. It is similar to
016 * {@link GenericFilterScalar} but requires two methods to be implemented by concrete sub-classes:
017 * {@code doPixelX(PixelSlice, int, int)} and {@code doPixelY(PixelSlice, int, int)} for the x- and y-pass,
018 * respectively, which are invoked in exactly this order. If the processed image has more than one component (e.g., a
019 * RGB color image), this filter is automatically and independently applied to all (scalar-valued) components. The
020 * remaining filter mechanics including multiple components, out-of-bounds coordinate handling, multiple passes and data
021 * copying are handled by this class and its super-class (see {@link GenericFilter}).
022 */
023public abstract class GenericFilterScalarSeparable extends GenericFilter {
024        
025        protected boolean doX = true;   // allow implementing sub-classes to deactivate x/y pass
026        protected boolean doY = true;
027        
028        // for progress reporting only
029        private int slice;
030        private int sliceMax = 1;
031        
032        private int iter = 0;
033        private int iterMax = 1;        // for progress reporting only
034        
035        
036        // apply filter to a stack of pixel planes (1 pass)
037        @Override
038        protected void runPass(PixelPack source, PixelPack target) {
039                sliceMax = source.getDepth();
040                for (int k = 0; k < sliceMax; k++) {
041                        //IJ.log("+++++++ starting slice " + k);
042                        this.slice = k;
043                        runSlice(source.getSlice(k), target.getSlice(k));       // default behavior: apply filter to each plane, place results in target
044                }
045        }
046        
047        // a bit wasteful, as we provide a separate target for each plane
048        private void runSlice(PixelSlice source, PixelSlice target) {
049                final int width = source.getWidth();
050                final int height = source.getHeight();
051                this.iterMax = width * height * 2;
052                this.iter = 0;
053                
054                if (doX) {
055                        // IJ.log("doing X-part =============================== ");
056                        for (int v = 0; v < height; v++) {
057                                for (int u = 0; u < width; u++) {
058                                        target.setVal(u, v, doPixelX(source, u, v));
059                                        this.iter++;
060                                }
061                        }
062                        target.copyTo(source);
063                }
064                
065                if (doY) {
066                        // IJ.log("doing Y-part =============================== ");
067                        for (int v = 0; v < height; v++) {
068                                for (int u = 0; u < width; u++) {
069                                        target.setVal(u, v, doPixelY(source, u, v));
070                                        this.iter++;
071                                }
072                        }
073                }
074                
075                this.iter = 0;
076        }
077        
078        // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
079
080        /**
081         * Applies a 1D filter operation in x-direction.
082         * This method must be implemented by concrete sub-classes.
083         * This method is invoked before {@link #doPixelY(PixelSlice, int, int)}.
084         * The source data are passed as a {@link PixelSlice} container, which
085         * holds the scalar values of one image component.
086         * The method {@link PixelSlice#getVal(int, int)} should be used to read
087         * individual pixel values. These data should not be modified but
088         * the (float) result of the single-pixel calculation must be returned.
089         * 
090         * @param source the scalar-valued data for a single image component
091         * @param u the current x-position
092         * @param v the current y-position
093         * @return the result of the filter calculation for this pixel
094         */
095        protected abstract float doPixelX(PixelSlice source, int u, int v);
096
097        /**
098         * Applies a 1D filter operation in y-direction.
099         * This method must be implemented by concrete sub-classes.
100         * This method is invoked after {@link #doPixelX(PixelSlice, int, int)}.
101         * The source data are passed as a {@link PixelSlice} container, which
102         * holds the scalar values of one image component.
103         * The method {@link PixelSlice#getVal(int, int)} should be used to read
104         * individual pixel values. These data should not be modified but
105         * the (float) result of the single-pixel calculation must be returned.
106         * 
107         * @param source the scalar-valued data for a single image component
108         * @param u the current x-position
109         * @param v the current y-position
110         * @return the result of the filter calculation for this pixel
111         */
112        protected abstract float doPixelY(PixelSlice source, int u, int v);
113        
114        // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
115        
116        @Override
117        protected final double reportProgress(double subProgress) {
118                double loopProgress = (this.iter + subProgress) / this.iterMax;
119                //IJ.log("   loopProgress = " + loopProgress);
120                double sliceProgress = (this.slice + loopProgress) / this.sliceMax;
121                //IJ.log("   sliceProgress = " + sliceProgress);
122                //System.out.println("reportProgress: GenericFilterScalar " + localProgress);
123                return super.reportProgress(sliceProgress);
124        }
125
126        
127}
